did.abstract: Collection consists of letters from John W. Hodnett to his sister, with comments on the hardships of war and the various campaigns in which he was engaged. He discusses cooking in camp and the lack of food food in general, his lack of shoes, the absence of tents, the position of Union troops and taking prisoners, the defense of Richmond, his desire for the war to end. There is one letter from T. J. Hodnett, who writes to his father, discussing the battle at Gettysburg and his regret that Vicksburg has fallen, along with his religious attitudes regarding the war.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: John W. Hodnett was a Confederate soldier in the 13th Regiment of the Georgia Volunteers. He was a resident of Meriwether County, Georgia. There are several John Hodnetts from that county, so it is difficult to provide more information about him. T. J. Hodnett was born in 1845 in Henry, Georgia, and also served in the same regiment. The relationship between these two men is unclear.
